items.title: Who gets to be called Aussie? Why these posters are causing another stir — 10 years on
items.summary: Artist Peter Drew is reinvigorating his conversation-starting artworks about what it really means to be Australian.

items.title: Two Australian Women's World Cup cricketers allegedly 'touched inappropriately' in India
items.summary: A man has been arrested and charged after the incident, which is believed to have happened on Thursday.

items.title: Midday News Bulletin 26 October 25
items.summary: Anthony Albanese will push for free trade at the upcoming ASEAN and APEC talks in Asia; two Australian women's cricket players allege assault, as a man is arrested in India; the Matildas beat Wales in a 2-1 victory in Cardiff, in star player Sam Kerr's long-awaited return to the team.

items.title: Labor moves to create Australia's first national environment watchdog
items.summary: The proposed environment protection agency is part of a raft of reforms to federal environmental laws.

items.title: Trump hits Canada with 10 per cent tariff hike in retaliation for anti-tariff TV ad
items.summary: The Canadian province of Ontario's ad uses the words of Republican former US president Ronald Reagan to criticise tariffs.

items.title: How a literacy and numeracy program is helping adults open up career options
items.summary: One in five Australians, or around three-million adults, have low literacy or numeracy skills - and it can have a big impact on how people are able to engage in every day life. Programs are in place across the country to help people improve their skills and achieve their life goals. Including one in Tasmania, helping adults become work ready.

items.title: Are aliens from space waiting to invade? Probably not, say the scientists
items.summary: The prospect for an alien invasion of Earth has been flooding the Internet in recent weeks thanks to the object 3-I-ATLAS currently hurtling through our solar system which some have warned may be an alien spacecraft that can attack our planet. Spoiler alert - NASA says it isn't. But even so, the fears of alien invasion are nothing new: in the final years of the nineteenth century, in his novel War of the Worlds, British author H G Wells wrote that 'minds immeasurably greater than our own, across the gulf of space, made their plans against us'. So what is the likelihood of an alien invasion? In this edition of Weekend One on One, Jason Wright, professor of astronomy and astrophysics at Penn State University and director of the Penn State Extraterrestrial Intelligence Centre looks into whether it could happen here.

items.title: The 'horrendous' gamble of fast-tracking the Trump-Albanese critical minerals deal
items.summary: The $13 billion deal has been widely celebrated, but some warn "stark changes" pose a risk to the environment and food.

items.title: INTERVIEW: 'Deaths of Despair': the deadly dangers of homelessness
items.summary: New data shows Australians experiencing homelessness are more likely to die from overdose, suicide or coronary heart disease, with potentially nine avoidable deaths every day. Data from the Australian Institute of Health and Welfare has found that around 43,200 people with a history of homelessness died between 2012 and 2013 alone from these types of causes. The median age was 55 years, far lower than the Australian median life expectancy of 81.1 years for men and 85.1 years for women. For women, gendered violence remains a leading cause of homelessness across Australia, impacting almost 67,000 people every year. Kate Colvin is the CEO of Homelessness Australia and she's been talking to SBS's Cameron Carr.

items.title: Anthony Albanese and Donald Trump are on their way to Asia. Here's what's on their agendas
items.summary: The prime minister and US president will visit Malaysia and South Korea for regional summits.

items.title: A 'queue' for execution: How Singapore's tough stance on crime resulted in Pannir's death
items.summary: Singapore has executed 14 prisoners this year. Among them was Pannir, hanged earlier this month for a first-time drug offence.

items.title: Revealed: Sanctioned Russian 'shadow' tankers in Australian oil product supply chains
items.summary: Data shows more than a third of oil tankers from Russia's 'shadow fleet' sanctioned in June are supplying Australian companies.

items.title: US imposes sanctions on Colombian president Gustavo Petro as feud escalates

items.title: Peanut butter loving babies are licking allergies, study suggests
items.summary: A decade after a landmark study proved that feeding peanut products to young babies could prevent them developing life-threatening allergies, a new US study has shown it's making a big difference in the real world. The study has found about 60,000 children in the United States have avoided developing peanut allergies after new guidance was issued in 2015 about when to introduce the allergen to youngsters.

items.title: INTERVIEW: Inside Sudan's deepening humanitarian crisis
items.summary: The civil war in Sudan has been raging for two and a half years and has generated arguably the largest humanitarian crisis on the planet. Often called the forgotten war, the conflict has torn apart the Northeast African country of 50 million people leaving around 12 million displaced from their homes and often with very little access to food, clean water and medicine. Reena Ghelani is the CEO of Plan International - one of the humanitarian organisations seeking to make a difference on the ground.

items.title: Traditional owners mark 40th anniversary of Uluru handback in London
items.summary: Anangu traditional owners have marked 40 years since Uluru Kata Tjuta National Park was handed back to their people. The handback was a landmark moment for Aboriginal land rights in Australia and a powerful recognition of the enduring connection between First Nations peoples and Country. The official celebrations have included a trip to London for a delegation of nine Anangu traditional owners, who met with High Commissioner to the UK Stephen Smith, and King Charles, as part of the official commemorations.

items.title: Why some Australians stand by the royal family despite the Prince Andrew scandal
items.summary: Polls show Australians have little sympathy for Prince Andrew — yet backing for the royal family and constitutional monarchy remains steady. Why?

items.title: The 'vicious cycle' that could see the most prescribed drugs in Australia become obsolete
items.summary: Common infections are becoming more resistant to treatment, and it's leaving experts worried for vulnerable groups.

items.summary: New search launched for missing teen Colleen Walker-Craig; Greens accuse government of weakening environmental protections; Gold Coast's pursuit of Craig Bellamy as head coach for 2027 is over.

items.title: Spotlight on US, Australia inflation; super balances hit new record
items.summary: The ASX-200 has ended the week in the red, as investors await the outcome of Donald Trump’s much-anticipated meeting with Chinese President Xi Jinping at the APEC Summit next week. Attention is also turning to the release of key September CPI data in the US, despite the government shutdown.

items.title: Families vow to fight on despite ex-soldier's acquittal over Bloody Sunday killings
items.summary: The only soldier ever prosecuted over a massacre of civilians in 1972 that became known as Bloody Sunday has been found not guilty of murder and attempted murder charges. The presiding judge at Belfast County Court has ruled that while he was satisfied the former paratrooper was among a group of soldiers who shot at civilians after a civil rights march, there was not enough evidence to convict him of the killings.

items.title: How does your balance compare? Australians reach a $172k super milestone
items.summary: There has also been a "historic" retirement shift, according to a peak body. Here's how much Australians have in their accounts.

items.summary: More aid is entering Gaza under a fragile ceasefire, but humanitarian agencies say it remains far from enough to meet the needs of its starving population. But discussions on how to achieve – and maintain – peace have coincided with Israel's Knesset narrowly advancing a bill to apply Israeli law to the occupied West Bank. It's being widely condemned as a preliminary step to approving total annexation.

President Donald Trump has announced broad sanctions on Russia’s two biggest oil giants, Rosneft and Lukoil. The measures mark a decisive shift in tone from the US, targeting the lifeblood of Russia’s economy in a bid to choke off Russia's Ukraine war funding

items.title: Australian-PNG defence treaty: 'one big fence securing two houses'
items.summary: The 31st Australia-Papua New Guinea Ministerial Forum was hosted in Canberra on Monday [[Oct 20]], focusing on the implementation of the historic mutual defence treaty signed between the two countries earlier this month. The 'puk-puk' treaty will see Australia invest millions of dollars in the PNG defence force. A key part of the deal is a taskforce to recruit PNG citizens into the Australian Defence Force, but this has been criticized by former PNG defence personnel who claim the pact is harmful because PNG does not share Australia's fear of China.

items.title: Investor warning about FOMO as gold stocks tumble
items.summary: The gold price has seen its worst one day fall in 12 years as gold stocks tumble after their recent run. Similarly, rare earths also slide. Meanwhile, the United Nations says it is important the ceasefire holds - to allow for aid deliveries to be scaled up in Gaza.

items.title: Breastfeeding reduces the risk of breast cancer, researchers say
items.summary: Australian researchers have found breastfeeding can protect women against breast cancer by building up their immunity. According to a new study, pregnancy and breastfeeding produces infection-fighting T-cells that help guard against abnormal cells that could develop into cancer.

items.title: Deals signed as Trump and Albanese meet; but what are the wider implications?

The agreement involves major US investment in Australian mining and processing projects, but has sparked criticism over fears it could give the US too much control over Australia’s resources and sovereignty.

items.title: 'Broke half the internet': Amazon cloud outage lasts 15 hours, triggering global chaos
items.summary: A massive internet outage has taken out thousands of websites, apps and services globally. The technical fault originated with U-S data centres operated by Amazon Web Services, which controls 30 per cent of the world's cloud computing market that underpins web-based services like apps and websites.

items.title: Diwali shines a light on culture for Australian family in Gujarat

SBS caught up with them in Gujarat, on India’s west coast. This story was produced in collaboration with SBS Gujarati Executive Producer Vatsal Patel.

items.title: 'How' not 'who' the question after Louvre crown jewels smash and grab

After the brazen theft of some of France's crown jewels in broad daylight, staff and union representatives say not enough has been done to guard the objects and people at one of the world's most famous galleries.

items.title: Police union boss likens Melbourne protest to Northern Ireland in the 1970s
items.summary: Premier Jacinta Allan blamed a "very small number" of counter-protesters for the violence and said they deserved to face "serious consequences".

items.title: Sussan Ley announces plan to give Australians income tax cuts, without details or costings
items.summary: The Coalition is planning tax cuts and policy reform in the lead-up to the next election, but details are scarce.

items.title: 'No violence, very professional': What we know about the Louvre jewellery heist
items.summary: Masked robbers broke into the Paris museum using a crane and angle grinders to steal French crown jewels worth tens of millions of dollars.

items.title: Gaza ceasefire to resume after Israeli strikes kill at least 26

items.summary: Only time will tell if these two very different personalities from opposite sides of the political spectrum will be able to gel.

items.title: A rich cultural heritage celebrated in lights: Diwali
items.summary: Diwali is the biggest festival in India and many South Asian countries, marking the victory of good over evil and the triumph of light over darkness. It is celebrated by more than a billion people around the world, including diaspora communities in Australia.

items.title: When is Diwali and what does the festival celebrate?
items.summary: The global festival of lights lasts five days.

items.title: How 'anti-foreign worker sentiment' is snuffing out the dreams of Australians in the US
items.summary: Rapid political change has shattered the dreams of some Australians who were looking to work or study in the US.

items.title: Could your dog be an addict? Scientists think so
items.summary: Does your dog seem to really, really love playing with a certain toy? It may be something more than harmless fun.

items.summary: Artificial intelligence has led to a "terrifying" new type of bullying, the education minister has warned.

items.summary: Reports the firebrand MP plans to defect to One Nation are not yet confirmed, but his options have been kept open.

items.title: Remains of another Israeli hostage in Gaza handed over by Hamas
items.summary: Israel says it has received nine of 28 bodies held in Gaza, with Hamas saying it needed heavy machinery and excavating equipment to speed up the process.

items.summary: Zelenskyy came to Washington after weeks of calls for Tomahawk missiles, hoping to capitalise on Trump's growing frustration with Putin.

items.title: Barking bad: The ruff road to recovery
items.summary: Dogs can become so attached to particular toys that they display behaviour that would be associated with addiction in humans. Researchers say when the dogs were deprived of their toys in the study, they became so fixated on what they'd lost that their blood pressure increased and they ignored everything else.

items.title: Prince Andrew renounces title amid renewed scrutiny over Epstein ties
items.summary: The move comes after new claims surfaced in Virginia Giuffre’s posthumous memoir detailing Andrew's alleged involvement with Jeffrey Epstein.

items.title: Prince Andrew renounces title amid renewed scrutiny over Epstein ties
items.summary: The move comes after new claims surfaced in Virginia Giuffre’s posthumous memoir detailing Andrew's alleged involvement with Jeffrey Epstein.

items.title: Long-lost diary tells a personal story of China's involvement in D-Day
items.summary: A long-lost diary from a Chinese war veteran has been discovered, detailing the participation of China's participation in D-Day. The 80-page diary was discovered in an abandoned Hong Kong flat, and details Lam Ping Yu's brush with death during the world's largest-ever sea, land and air armada on D Day during World War Two.

items.title: Champion of champions: Remembering Dr Charles Perkins 25 years after his death
items.summary: This weekend marks 25 years since the passing of Arrernte and Kalkadoon leader Dr Charles Perkins.

items.title: How Donald Trump became a hero in Israel
items.summary: The release of Israeli hostages saw Donald Trump hailed as a hero to the Jewish people this week. This is why he's getting all the credit.

items.title: Gold price warning as some traditional buyers tap out at record levels
items.summary: SBS Finance Editor Ricardo Gonçalves speaks with Oreana Private Wealth Chief Investment Officer Isaac Poole in Asia, who says some traditional gold buyers are tapping out of the market at current record levels, plus a look at the day's market action.

items.title: The quiet creep that's making Australian banking less 'inclusive and accessible'
items.summary: A decline in face-to-face banking services and cash facilities is harming some Australians more than others, advocates say.

items.title: KISS founding member and lead guitarist Ace Frehley dies at 74
items.summary: Ace Frehley, founding member of the glam rock band KISS, has died at 74 after complications following a recent fall.

items.title: Fears grow over truce's fragility amid concerns around hostages bodies, aid
items.summary: Israel is pressing Hamas to honour the ceasefire agreement and return the bodies of hostages still held in Gaza. This comes as satellite images show limited aid convoys entering the enclave through Kerem Shalom, while displaced Palestinians in Khan Younis endure worsening living conditions amid shortages of food, fuel, and clean water. With more than 67,900 Palestinians killed since 2023 and uncertainty over Rafah’s reopening, fears are growing that the fragile truce could collapse.

items.title: Australian military 'contingency planning' for possible Gaza troop deployment

items.title: Government considering offshore recognition of migrant skills
items.summary: Home Affairs Minister Tony Burke says the government is working on the possibility of an offshore recognition of skills. He says this will help save time and money for skilled migrants looking to move to Australia. In his address the Press Club in Canberra Mr Burke also flagged changes to inactive bank accounts to combat money laundering.

items.title: Australia’s rental affordability 'myth' that doesn’t match reality
items.summary: Workers in critical sectors are frequently locked out of affordable housing — and not just in capital cities, a new report says.

items.title: 'Bombs have stopped, but threats remain': The 'absolute catastrophe' inside Gaza

items.title: Israel delays reopening of crucial Gaza border, rules out aid transfers
items.summary: A key border crossing between Gaza and Egypt will remain closed, dashing hopes it would quickly open under a ceasefire deal between Israel and Hamas.

items.title: SPECIAL EPISODE: Inside the Gaza ceasefire: hostages, prisoners & a negotiator

items.title: Germany, NATO pledge billions in new Ukraine aid as Russia reels from fuel strikes
items.summary: Germany and NATO allies have pledged billions in new aid to Ukraine as the war nears its fourth winter, with Kyiv urging urgent air-defence support amid a sharp drop in foreign assistance. Meanwhile, Russia is grappling with fuel shortages following Ukrainian strikes, as President Donald Trump renews his criticism of Vladimir Putin over the prolonged conflict and Russia’s faltering economy.

items.title: Hamas-Israel ceasefire holds - but only just
items.summary: Two more bodies of deceased hostages have been handed over to the Red Cross by Hamas, following Israel's accusation that the militant group were failing to abide by the terms of the ceasefire deal. Aid is continuing to roll into Gaza despite threats from Israel that they would cut supplies and close border crossings. But there are heightened concerns for the fragile ceasefire, amid reports US President Donald Trump is considering allowing Israel to resume its military activities.

items.title: Trump confirms he authorised covert CIA operations in Venezuela
items.summary: Donald Trump said he was "looking at land now" after recently targeting alleged drug smuggling boats from Venezuela by sea.

items.title: Is your job burning you out? Experts say better boundaries and workplace connections can help
items.summary: Despite a growing awareness around mental health, research shows burnout in the workplace is still a major challenge. Experts say without proper training and healthy boundaries in the workplace, more and more Australians will consider leaving their jobs in the next year.

items.title: Madagascar braces for military rule as coup leader prepares to be sworn in
items.summary: The African Union said it was suspending Madagascar after a coup ousted President Andry Rajoelina.

items.title: Victorian government debates ground-breaking Treaty Bill
items.summary: The Victorian Government is debating a historic Statewide Treaty Bill, establishing Australia's first ever Treaty agreement between a state government and First Peoples in Victoria. If signed into law, the Treaty Bill will forge a path forward for First Peoples in Victoria to negotiate and influence the policy that affects community.

items.title: Warning Australia faces 'looming period of risk' as it awaits nuclear submarines
items.summary: As Australia awaits nuclear-powered submarines, a strategic policy think tank warns we're sitting vulnerable to potential threats.

items.summary: Acclaimed American soul musician D'Angelo has died at 51 after a "prolonged and courageous battle with cancer", his family says.

items.title: Middle East peace deal signed; so where to from here?
items.summary: World leaders have signed a historic Middle East deal at a summit in Egypt. It comes hours after Israel and Hamas exchanged detainees and hostages. Israel released nearly 2,000 Palestinians from Israeli prisons, and Gaza released the surviving Israeli hostages after two years in captivity.

items.title: Climate tipping points being crossed, scientists warn
items.summary: A large white coral reef containing important species and fossil traces has been discovered at a depth of more than 500 metres in the Gulf of Naples, in a rare discovery for the Mediterranean. But a new report suggests reefs like this might already be in danger, with global warming crossing dangerous thresholds sooner than expected and the world's coral reefs now in an almost irreversible die-off. It marks what scientists are describing as the first tipping point in climate-driven ecosystem collapse.

items.title: 'I don't have words': Cape Verde erupts in celebration after historic World Cup qualification
items.summary: The island nation is set to become one of the smallest countries to participate in football's showpiece event.

items.title: The new threat to Australia's potato industry - what is it and how can we deal with it?
items.summary: Of all Australian states, Tasmania is the biggest producer of potatoes, and a lot of what's grown here goes into potato products you would know well – hot chips, hash browns and wedges among them. But a new virus detected in recent months is causing concern. Growers are optimistic it can be managed, stressing it doesn't pose a risk to human health.

items.title: 'Eating mostly brown food': The 'devastating' juggle faced by a rising number of Australians
items.summary: With one in seven Australians living below the poverty line, researchers and advocates say that COVID-era universal income is the solution.

items.title: New super changes for low income earners and high balances & how geopolitics is impacting markets
